As Mike says: URI's are opaque from the client perspective. So any URI sche=
me would do. For instance http://hostname/organization?id=3D1234 (replace 1=
234 with any ID of your organization resources)

What you need is links in =
your representation. Assume you have a top-organizational unit at the well-=
known URI http://hostname/organization (no id supplied). At this URI you ge=
t HTML describing that particular organizational unit. Included in the HTML=
 you also get links to the related units:

  <a href=3D"http://hostname/org=
anization?id=3D5" rel=3D"child">Unit X</a>
  <a href=3D"http://hostname/org=
anization?id=3D12" rel=3D"child">Unit Y</a>

Now you can let your client br=
owse through your organization chart by following links.

You can also incl=
ude standard HTML forms for searching for units. Here you can have a text i=
nput where someone can enter the organizational path to a unit, and get a U=
RI back that points to the exact unit.

No need for special URI schemes :-)=


/J=F8rn
